article.title: Vista Point: Weekly Goings-On in Isla Vista
article.description: VOTING ON GOLD BEGINS SOON UC Santa Barbara’s Associated Students Elections voting will begin on April 23 at 8 p.m. Students have the opportunity to vote their peers into senatorial positions as wel...
article.content:
Sierra Deak/Daily Nexus

VOTING ON GOLD BEGINS SOON

UC Santa Barbara’s Associated Students Elections voting will begin on April 23 at 8 p.m. Students have the opportunity to vote their peers into senatorial positions as well as five executive positions. The NewCen project will also be on the ballot; the project would drastically remodel the current university center as well as raise student fees. In addition, several existing fees will be up for reaffirmation. Voting continues until April 26 at 4 p.m., at which time the polls will close.

 

PRINCESS MONONOKE MEETING

The Isla Vista Food Co-op will screen Princess Mononoke, a 1997 Japanese animated historical fantasy film written and directed by Hayao Miyazaki. The movie centers around issues pertaining to the environment, and the screening will transition into Earth Day weekend! The movie will begin at 5:30 p.m. on Friday and will close around 8:30 p.m. Popcorn will be served, so pull up a chair! The co-op is located at 6575 Seville Rd. in Isla Vista.

 

FREE DENTAL DAY

Santa Barbara Neighborhood Clinics will team up with the Rotary Club of Santa Barbara Sunrise on Friday to offer free dental services at the Goleta Neighborhood Dental Clinic. Dentists, health professionals and community volunteers from the Santa Barbara County area will be gathered at 164 Kinman Avenue to offer treatments including exams, x-rays, extractions, fillings and cleanings. Patients do not need dental insurance and will be assigned an appointment time at registration. Go get clean teeth!

 

FRAT DOES 911 EMERGENCY PROTOCOL PANEL

UCSB’s fraternity Zeta Beta Tau will hold a 911 emergency protocol panel at I.V. Theater on Thursday from 5:30 p.m. Several representatives from both on and off campus organizations will be there to provide knowledge and first-hand experiences about what happens when an individual calls 911. Any member of the UCSB Greek system who attends will be given SOE credit, but the panel is open to all UCSB students who wish to attend and learn more about calling 911. The theater is located at 960 Embarcadero del Norte, and the panel will close at 6:30 p.m.

 

PITCH PERFECT 3

A.S. Program Board will be showing free films at I.V. Theater on Tuesdays throughout Spring Quarter until May 29. The program board will be showing “Pitch Perfect 3,” directed by Trish Sie, this upcoming Tuesday at 7 p.m. and 10 p.m. Anna Kendrick, Rebel Wilson and Brittany Snow reprise their roles as Beca, Amy and Chloe, respectively. All starred in “Pitch Perfect” and “Pitch Perfect 2,” a franchise that explores a struggling acapella group. The next movie program board will be showing is “Annihilation” on May 1.

related.title: Structure Fire on Del Playa Drive
related.description: Santa Barbara Fire Department responded to a structure fire at 6767 Del Playa Drive in Isla Vista on Thursday night.
related.content:
Santa Barbara Fire Department responded to a structure fire at 6767 Del Playa Drive in Isla Vista on Thursday night.

Approximately four fire trucks came to the scene. Angie Banks / Daily Nexus

The fire began around 8:45 p.m. and was extinguished around 9:20 p.m.

The “entire balcony” was on fire, according to a Nexus reporter on scene.

The fire entered both units A and B within the building, according to police reports.

Santa Barbara Sheriff’s Office (SBSO) and the Isla Vista Foot Patrol (IVFP) both responded to the scene and evacuated nearby houses. They also closed off beach access near the location.

Police blocked off all traffic on Del Playa Drive and set up roadblocks on Camino del Sur and Camino Corto as well.

Crews began the “mop-up stage” around 9:13 p.m., according to police reports.

There are no current reports of injuries.

This article will be updated.

related.title: Future of I.V Government in Voters’ Hands
related.description: As primary elections quickly approach, student organizers and local government officials are making their second push toward a measure which would fund Isla Vista’s financially hamstrung government ...
related.content:
As primary elections quickly approach, student organizers and local government officials are making their second push toward a measure which would fund Isla Vista’s financially hamstrung government for the first time.

Sierra Deak / Daily Nexus

Measure R, a new ballot measure proposed by the Isla Vista Community Services District (CSD), would fund the fledgling government’s operations by imposing an eight percent tax on electricity, garbage disposal, gas, sewage and water services. The ballot measure will be on Isla Vistans’ June 5, 2018, primary election ballot.

The I.V. CSD was created on Nov. 9, 2016, after the passage of Measure E with an overwhelming 87 percent of the vote, but the new government was deprived of financial stability when Measure F failed to garner the necessary 66.67 percent of the vote, falling short by about six percent.

Measure R is essentially a second attempt to pass a user utility tax (UUT), the same goal Measure F sought to accomplish in 2016. The ballot language for the measure has changed since the UUT’s first appearance at the polls, though only slightly.

While on the 2016 ballot, Measure F included the contingency that the UUT would go into effect with the creation of a then-nebulous CSD. Measure R now lists the particular services the tax would fund.

According to the ballot language registered with the county’s clerk-recorder, the UUT would explicitly fund any of the following services: improvements to parking, public safety, lighting and sidewalks.

The tax could also be used to provide tenant mediation services, create a municipal advisory council and operate facilities like the Community Room the CSD currently meets at for its twice-monthly board meetings and the burgeoning Community Center.

In order to place Measure R on the June primary ballot, the CSD Board of Directors first voted on the language citizens would see on their voting slips and then submitted the proposed question to the County of Santa Barbara Board of Supervisors, which later approved the phrasing at a board meeting.

Since its creation, the CSD has found its organizational framework, hired legal counsel, expanded the Community Service Organization’s escort services, piloted a tenant mediation program with the Santa Barbara Legal Aid Foundation and hired an interim General Manager, all while operating mainly on a $200,000 donation from UC Santa Barbara.

In an interview with the Nexus on Wednesday, I.V. CSD President Ethan Bertrand said the key difference between the 2016 vote and this year’s is that the CSD has found its footing, proving it can do a lot with a little.

Support for Measure R is mounting within student activist networks and some government circles. UC Santa Barbara’s Campus Democrats began campaigning for the measure last Monday, while the “Yes on Measure R” campaign has been active since mid-March.

While the I.V. Recreation and Parks District has not made an official statement supporting the measure, Third District Supervisor Joan Hartmann issued a statement on Wednesday “strongly in support” of Measure R. Hartmann has personally contributed $6,000 toward the campaign and will actively fundraise and canvass for its passage, she said.

Hartmann said the measure’s passage would allow for the CSD to thrive and provide effective services to its unique demographic.

“Due to its great density, diversity, poverty level, and demographics dominated by a young student population … Isla Vista has an even greater need for services and infrastructure than other unincorporated areas in the County,” Hartmann said in her statement.

While proponents of the tax have sought to spread their message through door-to-door canvassing and tabling, opponents have voiced their displeasure toward the tax, primarily through flyers.

Chuck Eckert, treasurer of anti-UUT group Isla Vistans Against Higher Taxes, told the Nexus on Wednesday that the group has been distributing flyers advocating for a “no” vote on the measure.

The flyers claim that I.V. residents’ taxes are far too high and calls on them to voice their dissent. The exact cost of the UUT for individual residents is still undetermined, according to CSD Secretary and Director Spencer Brandt. The CSD plans to present a revenue estimate at their next board meeting, Brandt said.

Eckert said he is against the measure’s passage because he believes the I.V. government does not need additional funding “to do what they have already done.” He also said services like tenant mediation duplicate already available services like the Community Housing Office and other resources offered by UCSB and the County of Santa Barbara.

A version of this article appeared on pg. 3 of the April 12, 2018 issue of the Daily Nexus.

related.title: Vista Point
related.description: Catch up on the goings-on in Isla Vista this week!
related.content:
Sierra Deak/Daily Nexus

Pizza with the Press: Daily Nexus Town Hall

On Thursday, April 12, from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m, the Daily Nexus will be hosting a Town Hall at Rincon Brewery. We want to hear about your questions and concerns regarding our coverage, and we want to open up our reporting process so members of our community have a chance to share their opinions with us. If you feel uncomfortable asking a question in person, there will be an anonymous Google form for any comments or suggestions that you may have. See you there, Gauchos!

Indian Food Tasting

Need a flavor boost, Gauchos? On Thursday, April 12, the Isla Vista Food Co-Op is hosting a HowGood demo with Maya Kaimal Fine Indian Foods from 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. Stop by and try five flavors of ready-made “dal,” or Indian lentils. Bring your friends to try this sustainable and organic meal!

The Mallards with The Swells

On Friday, April 13, from 8 p.m. to 12 a.m., The Mallards will be performing with The Swells on 6508 Del Playa Drive. Dress up in a spooky costume and stop by with friends to hear some groovy tunes. Those wearing the best costumes will get to dance on stage with both bands. The Swells will be performing at 9 p.m., and The Mallards will be performing at 10:30 p.m.

IVCSD Disaster Preparedness

Come participate in a conversation around disaster preparedness in Isla Vista hosted by the I.V. Community Services District on Friday, April 13, from 12:15 p.m. to 1:30 p.m in the Isla Vista Community Room. Learn about how you can be ready for a natural disaster from Isla Vista’s local government.

County Composting Workshop

Do you care about the environment? Do you want to learn more about how you can help the environment? If you answered “yes” to both of these questions, don’t forget to come to the County Composting Workshop hosted by the Isla Vista Food Co-Op on Saturday, April 14, from 12 p.m. to 1 p.m. The Associated Students Department of Public Worms and the Santa Barbara County Resource Recovery and Waste Management Division will be there to teach you about the kind of food that can be composted and the usage of worms. There will also be demonstrations with compost and earth machines. Bring your friends, enjoy some free snacks and learn about compost.

Grocery Shopping on a Budget

Are you unsure how to effectively budget your grocery money? On Monday, April 16, from 6 p.m. to 7 p.m., the Isla Vista Food Co-Op is hosting Grocery Shopping on a Budget, an event to teach students how to grocery shop on a budget of $50 a week. There will be demonstrations from the cookbook entitled “Good and Cheap: Eat Well on $4 a Day.” The Co-Op will be raffling off the cookbook at the event. Come learn how to utilize your grocery money wisely.

Free Tuesday Films: “The Disaster Artist”

Associated Students Program Board is hosting a free film called “The Disaster Artist” on Tuesday, April 17, from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. at the I.V. Theatre. “The Disaster Artist” is about two friends who travel to Los Angeles and end up writing and directing their own movie. Bring your friends, some movie snacks and enjoy the film. Skip the movie theatre and swing by I.V. theatre.

The Global Environmental Justice Movement: Defining and Engaging

On Tuesday, April 17, Dr. David Pellow will be giving a talk on the global environmental justice movement from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. at Rincon Brewery. Come learn about the future of the environmental justice movement and listen to Brengrass, which is a band of Bren school students. Not to mention, there will be free pizza. Swing by to get educated, eat some great food and listen to some groovy tunes.

A version of this story appeared on pg. 3 of the April 12, 2018 issue of the Daily Nexus.
